Osa Conservation: Lifetime exploration Part 1 Raw data

Osa Conservation: Lifetime exploration Chris Beirne Part 1 Raw data This section summarizes the movement locations for all the tracking devices within Osa Conservation’s movement ecology project. Last data request: 2024-07-28 23:30:46.373078 The project currently contains 115 tag deployments and 1920470 locations. The number of species by country is: Locations per country and species: Table 1.1: Summary: Locations and individuals by country country taxon_canonical_name n_locs n_inds costa_rica Cathartes aura 106283 5 costa_rica Coragyps atratus 88185 5 costa_rica Leopardus pardalis 849 4 costa_rica Puma concolor 2982 2 costa_rica Sarcoramphus papa 1016961 36 costa_rica Tapirus bairdii 7052 2 ecuador Sarcoramphus papa 49022 6 peru Atelocynus microtis 173 3 peru Cathartes aura 30749 4 peru Cathartes melambrotus 257939 17 peru Coragyps atratus 35705 4 peru Leopardus pardalis 140 3 peru Panthera onca 2140 3 peru Puma concolor 622 1 peru Sarcoramphus papa 321665 19 1.0.1 Costa Rica Note this is raw unfiltered data We currently have deployed 54 devices in Costa Rica: 1.0.2 Peru We have deployed 54 devices in Peru: 1.0.3 Ecuador We have deployed 6 devices in Ecuador:

Part 2 Data cleaning - Vultures All tracking devices come with errors, and each track must be checked visual and cleaned of outliers before analysis. This page shows this process for each animal within the project. It has been automated so that we always have access to a stardardised and cleaned locations database. Animals are cleaned in the order in which they occur in the database. 2.0.1 Vultures 2.0.2 OC8 - Cathartes melambrotus First observation: 2021-06-10 11:00:17 Last observation: 2024-07-28 15:00:28 Active for: 1144.2 days 2.0.3 OC6 - Part 3 Data cleaning - Mammals All tracking devices come with errors, and each track must be checked visual and cleaned of outliers before analysis. This page shows this process for each mammal within the project. It has been automated so that we always have access to a stardardised and cleaned locations database.

3.1 Tapirs For the tapir collars we use the Telonics - TGW-4577-4 model, wioth data sent through the Iridium system. They have low voltage and mortality alerts. There are two types of location data these collars collect - regular GPS and QFP. QFP’s are Quick Fix Positions and use less battery than a standard GPS fix. Units can be configured to collect GPS, QFP, or a mix of the two location types - we collect a mix. Our collars collect QFP’s when there is no GPS signal available. Succeded = a successful GPS location Resolved QFP = a successful QFP location Resolved QFP = an uncertain QFP location (lower quality) Unresolved QFP = A poor quality QFP Lets explore the implications of these different fix types for one individual - Juancito. 3.1.1 Juancito (CR) ## Reading layer `OC_trails2' from data source ## `/Users/runner/work/Osa-Conservation-Movement-Ecology-Lifetime-Exploration/Osa-Conservation-Movement-Ecology-Lifetime-Exploration/shapefiles/OC_trails2.shp' ## using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 204 features and 1 field ## Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING ## Dimension: XY ## Bounding box: xmin: -83.35712 ymin: 8.393359 xmax: -83.30851 ymax: 8.429462 ## Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 First observation: 2022-05-29 18:01:25 Last observation: 2023-11-09 04:02:20 Active for: 528.4 days To date we have 4011 fixes from Juancito. Of those, they are of the following types. Var1 Freq Percentage Resolved QFP 2380 0.59 Resolved QFP (Uncertain) 80 0.02 Succeeded 537 0.13 Unresolved QFP 1014 0.25 Plot of the raw data: We can then explore how these different fix types introduce error into the locations: NOTE ZOOM IN! So there is unreliability in all of the QFP estimates, but the GPS look great (not much spread). Lets explore the error around each type of fix (if it has an estimate present): Only GPS data has an error in meters (max 127m): QFP data has error in doplar estimates: So we have a huge spread in error. Lets subset to anything with a hdop <10,and resolved. This substantially reduced the spread but still leaves a couple of issues - notable outliers. We should also use ctmm (as in the vultures) to find errors: 3.1.2 Tuva (CR) First observation: 2023-04-14 08:01:55 Last observation: 2024-07-22 04:01:16 Active for: 464.8 days To date we have 3041 fixes from Tuva. Of those, they are of the following types. Var1 Freq Percentage Resolved QFP 1585 0.52 Resolved QFP (Uncertain) 60 0.02 Succeeded 326 0.11 Unresolved QFP 1070 0.35 Which means even less “resolved” locations. Plot of the raw data: We can then explore how these different fix types introduce error into the locations: NOTE ZOOM IN! So there is unreliability in all of the QFP estimates, but the GPS look great (not much spread). Lets explore the error around each type of fix (if it has an estimate present): Only GPS data has an error in meters (max 127m): QFP data has error in dopler estimates: So we have a huge spread in error. Lets subset to anything with a hdop <10,and resolved. This substantially reduced the spread but still leaves a couple of issues. We should also use ctmm (as in the vultures) to find errors:

3.2 Jaguars For carnivores we use Vectronic collars. Large carnivores we have VERTEX Plus (GPS + ACC) and VERTEX Vision (GPS + ACC + Video) 3.2.1 Killa (PE) VERTEX Plus collar. Part 5 Mammal Tracking When tracking mammals it is good to understand their home range, and where they have been in the preceeding weeks. For each individual we prodice a lifetime heatmap, and a last 4 weeks heatmap - all from cleaned data. 5.0.1 Juancito LIFETIME ## Reading layer `landmass' from data source ## `/Users/runner/work/Osa-Conservation-Movement-Ecology-Lifetime-Exploration/Osa-Conservation-Movement-Ecology-Lifetime-Exploration/landmass.shp' ## using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 2 features and 168 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension: XY ## Bounding box: xmin: -87.11767 ymin: 5.515082 xmax: -77.16327 ymax: 11.20994 ## Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 LAST MONTH OF COLLAR LIFE 5.0.2 Tuva LIFETIME ## Reading layer `landmass' from data source ## `/Users/runner/work/Osa-Conservation-Movement-Ecology-Lifetime-Exploration/Osa-Conservation-Movement-Ecology-Lifetime-Exploration/landmass.shp' ## using driver `ESRI Shapefile' ## Simple feature collection with 2 features and 168 fields ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension: XY ## Bounding box: xmin: -87.11767 ymin: 5.515082 xmax: -77.16327 ymax: 11.20994 ## Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 LAST MONTH
